BAHRAIN RECEIPT.\A Extract cf paragraphs 1-8, 13 E. 14 of xieport dated the 30th March, 1947, by the Telecommunications Attache in the Middle East. 1. Although the situation regarding the development of the Bahrein telephone system has improved considerably since the previous visit in October, 1946, and a firm decision has been taken by Cable and Wireless, Ltd., to install a modern automatic exchange, several major difficulties will dcibtless arise as a result of the high water level at various points along the proposed main cable routes, but these cannot be dealt with until the. actual work of installation commences. It is hoped that the necessary exchange and ancillary equipment will start to arrive by the middle of,the year, and while no accurate forecast can be given as to the date of completion, on account of the difficulties referred to above, it is to be hoped that the project will be well advanced by the end of 1947. 2 . . Cwing to the dela:/ in final approval of the scheme, and the increased cost of land, materials and construction charges, the cost of the whole installation will be considerably in excess of that originally estimated, and while it has been tentatively agreed with the Bahreih Government that telephone rentals and charges will remain at the present level, in the hope that some eventual reduction might be possible, it now seems doubtful, even estimating for the maximum possible number of subscribers, if the annual revenue will represent sufficient reutrn on capital expenditure to permit of any such reduction in the existing charges. 3. Arrangements have been made with the Bahrein Petroleum Company to link the new town system with the Company’s new exchange being installed at Awali, but some technical liaison v/ill be necessary, particularly as the Oil Company are understood to be buying American pattern automatic exchange equipment.which may not work direct into the system being installed in the town. Some appreciable improvements in the handling of external telegraph traffic can be expected shortly, when a direct circuit is opened between Bahrein and London, and, so long as the Brhrein Fao submarine cable is in operation, this link will also provide a useful alternative routeing for Iraq traffic (as opposed to the normal route by wireless London to Cfiro and thence Cairo to Baghdad). Faster handling of external traffic for the Bahrein Petroleum Comapny is also being arranged by the installation of a teleprinter circuit between Awali and the Town Office of Cable and tireless • Lj td. 5. x t was suggested some time ago that radio-telephone facilities should be established between Bahrein and London, and information has now been received by the Oil Company, as yet unconfirmed through official channels, that circuits will be opened both to London and New York by the end of the year. It seems likely that the New York circuit will be established as a relay via London, as traffic would probably not justify the installation of a separate powerful transmitter, while suitable equipment for the London circuit is at present lying crated at the Bahrein wireless station. The M anager of Cable and Vvireless ltd. has not yet received instructions as to whether the equipment is to be installed in Bahrein. 6 . Description of Enclosures Copy of Foreign Office despatch No. 88 of 11th June 1948 to the British Middle East Office, on the termination of Mr. Sinclair^ appointment as Middle East Telecommunications Attache.4 COPY No. 88 (XSQ3/102D( 37/48)) FOREIGN OFFICE, S.W.l. • 11th June, 1948. • Sir, With reference to my despatch number 134 of 10th July 1947, I have to inform you that, after full discussion in London, and owing to the pressing need for economy at the present time, it has been decided that it is necessary to discontinue the post of Telecommunications Attache in the Middle East. Mr. Sinclair^ appointment is therefore being terminated on 15th June. 2. Arrangements have been made for the performance, so • far as possible, of the duties hitherto performed by Mr. Sinclair by the overseas staff of Messrs Cable and Wireless, which concern is now exclusively controlled by His Majesty's Government. You and the heads of the diplomatic missions in the Middle East should therefore call on the services of the local representative of Messrs Cable and Wireless when in need of advice on telecommunications.Representatives of the firm are resident in most Middle Eastern countries: where there is no resident representative enquiries should be addressed, in the first instance, to the Divisional Manager in Cairo, to whom the local managers and offjeers in charge are subordinate, 3. Copies of this despatch are being sent to His Majesty's Representatives at Cairo, Tehran, Baghdad, Jedda, Angora, Athens, Addis Ababa, Amman, Beirut, Damascus and Bahrain, and to His Majesty’s Consuls-General at Jerusalem and Haifa. I am, with great truth and regard, Sir, Your obedient Servant, (For the Secretary of State). Sgd. G.H. Middleton. J.M. Troutbeck, Esq., K.C.M.G., etc. etc. etc., British Middle East Office.

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. Circled serial numbers (red for received correspondence; blue/black for issued correspondence) refer to entries in the notes at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 24; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-14 and an additional foliation/pagination sequence between ff 15-23; these numbers are written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file discusses the position of Middle East Telecommunications Adviser, later Attaché, which was created in May 1946, with Herbert Gray Sinclair appointed to the post, but was discontinued in June 1948.Included in the file are details of the responsibilities of the position; a tour of the Middle East taken by the adviser in 1946; a report on telecommunications in Bahrain and Sharjah in 1947; and a proposal to establish a telephone or telegraph line between Dubai and Sharjah owing to the increased traffic between the two places.A series of file notes which were maintained as a record of the correspondence in the volume can be found at folios 21-23.
